Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Supplemental Fluid Administration on Postoperative Wound Infections in Elective Colon Resections

Trial_Design.evidence: patients undergoing open colon resection were randomly assigned

Intervention.evidence: small volume (8 mL·kg⁻¹·h⁻¹, n=124) or large volume (16-18 mL·kg⁻¹·h⁻¹, n=129) fluid management

Objective.evidence: This study evaluates whether supplemental fluid administration during and after elective colon resections reduces postoperative wound infections.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the incidence of surgical wound infections, diagnosed by purulent exudate with culture-positive pathogenic bacteria or CDC criteria, assessed by a blinded observer within 15 days post-surgery.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: patients undergoing open colon resection were randomly assigned

Number_Randomised.evidence: small volume (8 mL·kg⁻¹·h⁻¹, n=124) or large volume (16-18 mL·kg⁻¹·h⁻¹, n=129)

Result_Outcome.evidence: 14 patients developed surgical wound infections, compared to 11 in the large fluid group (P=0.46)

Harms.evidence: No significant adverse events were reported in either group.
